awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Full Arch Device for a Comprehensive Dental Hygiene Routine
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is that the proposed device will disrupt the dental industry. This novel oral hygiene device will ultimately replace the need to brush teeth. The initial market will be dental implants and prosthetics in adult patients in the United States. With epidemiological data projecting an expanding elderly population, this device will be beneficial for geriatric populations that especially lack access to cost-effective and quality oral health care. If successful, the envisioned device will be a high-impact innovation that revolutionizes personalized oral hygiene care and heightens the standards and quality of care.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel comprehensive oral hygiene device that capitalizes on the science behind fluid dynamics and sanitization using light therapy. Fluid jet will be used to target high-risk dental areas at once. The envisioned device will significantly enhance the effectiveness of fluid-based plaque debridement. Furthermore, by incorporating a novel light-sensitive fluid, the system will completely disinfect all areas of the mouth to simplify the dental hygiene routine. This device challenges the existing oral health paradigm that mechanical action is the most effective mode of plaque and food debris debridement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we aimed to develop a novel personalized oral hygiene device using fluid dynamics and photodynamic therapy to effectively clean and disinfect high-risk areas of the mouth. In doing so, we sought to challenge the long-held belief that mechanical action alone is the most effective method for plaque and debris removal, and ultimately replace the need to brush teeth to maintain one's oral health.

With the support of the I-Corp award, our team was able to significantly advance our understanding of what potential end-users of our device would demand. This process constituted market research and direct engagement with a diverse group of potential patients (248 in total) with varying oral health needs and dental hygiene enthusiasts. We thus gained valuable insights into user preferences, concerns, and expectations. For example, a statistically significant portion of users expressed a preference for oral healthcare products that are chemically derived from natural sources. Another significant portion of users listed cost as a key barrier to not improving current oral healthcare practices. Such insights allowed us to refine our device's design and functionality, ensuring it not only meets our internal clinical efficacy standards but also aligns with the convenience, comfort, and usability that end-users desire.

Furthering the technological development of our novel oral hygiene device was another critical accomplishment made possible by the i-Corp award. Leveraging the insights gained from potential end-users, our engineering team is in the process of experimenting with different photochemical solutions to measure their efficacy. Furthermore, we have made advancements in modeling the fluid dynamics that would be necessary to ensure complete coverage of the mouth, including hard-to-reach areas. We are thus optimizing the device's performance, ensuring it can provide superior, personalized oral hygiene when compared to brushing alone.

Lastly, the I-Corp award enabled our team to attend several relevant conferences, which were instrumental in keeping us abreast of the latest advancements in oral hygiene technology and the broader field of dental care. These conferences offered invaluable opportunities to engage with leading experts, share our findings, and gather feedback on our device's design and functionality. This exposure not only informed our understanding of the technical and commercial risks associated with our device but also allowed us to establish important connections within the dental and oral health community, fostering collaborations that may prove to be crucial for our project's future development and success.

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2024
Modified by: Radi   Masri
